medical_history.chief_complaint: Presentation of primary adrenal insufficiency and progressive hyperpigmentation in patients with nonclassic lipoid congenital adrenal hyperplasia.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: Patient 1 experienced fever and vomiting at 2 years of age and was hypoglycemic during a viral illness at 4 years. Progressive hyperpigmentation prompted referral at 4.5 years. Patient 2 showed hyperpigmentation at 1.5 years, with investigation revealing low cortisol and elevated ACTH at 2.2 years. Patient 3 exhibited similar progressive pigmentation and was evaluated at 2.8 years.
medical_history.past_medical_history: All patients had primary adrenal insufficiency with varying levels of cortisol and ACTH. Patient 1 had undetectable cortisol, and the other patients had low cortisol but retained normal male genitalia.
medical_history.family_history: The two brothers (patients 2 and 3) are from a consanguineous family. The mutations identified (Val187Met and Arg188Cys) suggest a genetic link.
